title: If I'm on workers comp and struggling to pay debt may I file for bankruptcy and if yes will it have any bad effect on it ?
question: So far I've been on workers comp for about 7 months
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Workers' compensation
answers:
If you are otherwise eligible for bankruptcy, either chapter 7 or chapter 13, there will be no effect on your worker's compensation benefits. In California, either of the statutory exemption schemes will protect your future worker's compensation income. But, as noted you must qualify to file under what is called the "Means Test" and the past worker's compensation income, including any lump sum you might have received in the six months prior to filing the bankruptcy, will be considered.

You will certainly need to review your unique situation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. That review will get you the complete answer you are looking for.
There is no problem with you filing a Chapter & Bankruptcy. Your Worker's compensation benefits will not be effected. Good luck.
Your workers comp income is counted for bankruptcy purposes. However any settlement is likely an exempt asset under chapter 7 or 13. You should still disclose this to an attorney who can help you.

Filing for bankruptcy will not effect your worker's comp but the amount you are receiving from worker's comp, and any other income sources, will be used to determine which type of bankruptcy you qualify for.

As my esteemed colleagues such as Mr. Brumer (no relation) have indicated, your best bet at this point is to make an appointment with an attorney who is well-versed in bankruptcy matters. Most will take your call and offer a free consultation. The first move is the most important one. You need to make the call.

It is very unfortunate that your worker's compensation benefit is not enough to cover you bills. Rather than exhaust all your income attempting to do so, reducing or eliminating your bills may be a better option. As the other local San Diego attorneys have indicated, you can get a free consultation to weigh all your options. Good luck and I hope you get the assistance you seek.

The money that you receive from workers comp does count as income for purposes of determining what type of bankruptcy you may be eligible to file. (Any local bankruptcy attorney can help you work through the Means Test that is required to see what you can file.)

Filing bankruptcy will not affect your eligibility to receive workers comp.

If you think that there may be a large settlement from workers comp in the future because of your injury, make sure to discuss that possibility with the attorney that you talk to about filing bankruptcy.

There is no way to know if you will have problems filing a case, as that requires a lot more information. Your benefits won't be changed just because there is a filing, but that is just one of many questions to discuss before filing a case.

Recommend you get a free consultation with a local bankruptcy attorney in your area. Whether you may file or not depends on your income, from all sources, and if it exceeds the Means Test.

Here's a brief primer: http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/current-monthly-income-the-bankruptcy-means-test.html

Best of luck!
